The sequel offers a satisfying conclusion to the story, but it has lost most of its predecessor's horror charm by giving the player fully automatic weapons and unlimited ammo/battery resupply. It sports a few new enemy types, which is refreshing, and a new GUI with a compass that actually shows where north is, which is nice. Being a quarter as long as the original, though, it is a tough sale - grab it when it's discounted if you liked the first game.

The original Alan Wake was a recent favourite of mine and as this was released not too long after. I expected much of the same. I was dissapointed overall. The story in the original was definitely one of the factors that caused me to enjoy it. The story in this however is very lame. It is convoluted and underwhelming where the previous impressed. I am also dissapointed that they made this more action based as they had a good ratio of story/action/adventure in the original. Another negative is the fact that realistically the enviroments and story have enough material that would last two hours and could have been a pretty cool DLC to Alan Wake. However instead you are forced to repeat the whole game pretty much three times before it is complete due to a 'time loop' (Told you it was lame). Ironically enough I would recommend this if you enjoyed the original (especially the story or action) as it does follow on from the original and adds some clarity and depth to some of the unresolved questions I had after the first story. Would recommend waiting for a sale. 5/10

American Nightmare is part of the Alan Wake universe. If you did not play Alan Wake before, the story will feel strange to you.

A short but entertaining piece. Reuse of environment felt in line with ingame lore. Still, its something like an epilogue rather than a self-contained game proper.

Alan's Wake American Nightmare is the pseudo follow-up/se to the well received Alan Wake. It is a 3rd person shooter which controls exactly the same as the first game. American Nightmare improves drastically on one of the few low points of the original Alan Wake, the combat. A.N. adds several new weapons and enemy types. These additions would have been welcome earlier, since it grew tiresome using the same 4 weapons in Alan Wake and fighting the same enemies over the 10 hours the game took to beat. However, I could see how the weaponry might not have fit in that atmosphere. The variations in the enemy types help keep the combat fresh as you continue through the estimated 3-4 hour campaign.

The real standout in Alan Wake, the story, really takes a backseat in American Nightmare to the improved combat. While it will catch your attention at the beginning, I eventually found myself just wanting it to be over. Most of that I believe is due to the Groundhog Day esque nature of this installment, where you will be going through some of the same areas and events multiple times. It just fails to really engross you all the way through like Alan Wake did.

Speaking of the environments, they are a nice change of pace from the Pacific Northwest. The events take place in Night Springs, Arizona, a fictional town which is the setting of an in-game TV show. You will be running around through some desert landscape for a few hours, but this game is shorter so it doesn't wear out its welcome like the forest did.

The graphics have seen a slight improvement from the previous game, with the character animation looking much better, but still not stellar. The sound is also fantastic once again, with some great soundtrack moments during some battles.

I would recommend American Nightmare to fans of the original Alan Wake for two reasons. If you liked the combat, which some did, you will love the additions to the weaponry and enemies. If you liked the story, which most did, you will be interested in finding out what happens next to our protagonist. If you have not played Alan Wake, I would recommend picking that up before trying out American Nightmare. There are too many spoilers for the events of the first game, and it would ruin the experience.

Grade: B-

I loved this game to no end, it is by far one of my favorite games of all time.
I actualy liked it better than the original, lemme do a pro con thingy.
Pros:

Better weapons and combat.

Arcade action is a blast.

Most sadistic villain I have ever fought, providing a extremley satasfying ending.

More cool soundtrack.

Cons:

Story gets repetitive since alan only visits 3 small areas.

The whole time you will meet 4 people, 3 random girls and mr scratch, all the girls are unintresting and do nothing to better the story.

Camera angles can be realy annoying at times.

Its is absolutley manditory to zoom in now, no more just shining the light around to preserve batteries.

While Im on the topic of batteries, they are way to easy to get.

Normal mode provides little challenge, I was able to mow down 2 king hillbillys with a normal shotgun and flare gun without a problem.

After you beat the game, you cannot get the soundtrack for listening in game, or download, like the base game gave you.

Im pretty sure all multiplayer leaderboards have been hacked for #1 score.

Spiders. Why? The server no purpose other than to annoy you a little bit.

There are realy only a few weapons you'll ever use.

A few suggestions:

Co-op arcade mode would be a fun addition.

Loadouts, arcade mode would do good with loadouts.

Tighten the physisics up a bit, everything feels a bit to light (hehe, see what I did there?).

More inspired characters please?

Better enemys. The taken are not zombies, I would like to see more then 3 enemy models, and the special takens only get one model.

Name it better. Was the original Alan Wake not in america or something?

More TV shows, I know you were actualy in the TV show in this game, but some of my favorite parts of alan wake were pausing to watch Night Springs.

Less linear please, the original alan wake was linear, but it gave the allusion of being open level.

Cars?  Why doesnt alan just drive through the gates right up to wherever he's going? And, did he seriously drive a FREAKIN MINIVAN?

More special taken. Even with the special taken, there was realy only 3 types. Charger, Crow, King hillbilly. Oh, I forgot the flashbangers, Im not even going to count the spiders...

Overall rating: 9/10, excellent game, there is no excuse for not buying this game and the original.

From reading about this game online, I got the impression that this wasn't directly related to the first game, and was in fact non-canon; an alternate timeline from the first game, possibly even a prequel.

It isn't.

What it is, is a totally awesome direct sequel of the first game. If you liked the original Alan Wake then you've got to play this one as well. It continues on the same plot from the first game, and brings it through to a satisfying conclusion (one which many felt the original game lacked). If the base game of Alan Wake is part one, then the DLC for the original game, combined American Nightmare, is part two.

It took me about 6 hours to complete, according to Steam, so bear that in mind when you're looking to buy it.

It's just as satisfying and fun as the first game, with some new enemies and a different environment format. Instead of the more linear style of the first game, this one gives you three open-world areas to explore and complete tasks in. They aren't huge, but they don't feel small, and I think any bigger would make them a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ to traverse.

American Nightmare is a must-play for fans of the original. However if you haven't played the first one, don't even touch this American Nightmare until you have,

A cool addition to the Alan Wake franchise. The story mode is relatively short but nicely done, well paced and not too hard on normal difficulty. Graphics are just as good as the original Alan Wake, and the game plays well with some small but welcome changes to gameplay such as unlocking weapons after finding manuscript pages. Quite an enjoyable few hours. There's also the nice addition of the arcade mode for some short spells of blasting action.

+ Great spin-off if you enjoyed the 1st game
+ Things to find that gives you a backstory of the original game and about monsters.
+ Arcade to play after you completed the story
+ Gameplay isn't hard (only NIGHTMARE mode)
- Some locations and objectives are re-used (You'll see by yourself)
- Enemies' attacks are hard to evade
- Story not good as the 1st game (More like Alan Wake trying to defeat his doppleganger, I enjoyed it anyway)
It's always on sale and it's worth even if it's not, BUT buy it if you played the 1st game only. A good game if you want something that isn't a DLC for the original game and you want to keep playing Alan Wake. You can play the arcade mode if you wanna some action-based gameplay and no story.

✓ Good followup to the original storyline
✓ Suprisingly well narrated and directed
✓ Has a different colour tone than the original game
✓ Very intriguing atmosphere, well put together

✘ No Linux support.

American Nightmare is part of the Alan Wake universe. If you did not play Alan Wake before, the story will feel strange to you.

A short but entertaining piece. Reuse of environment felt in line with ingame lore. Still, its something like an epilogue rather than a self-contained game proper.

Next game: Quantum Break.

If this game ever goes on sale BUY IT. It's smart, twisted, charming and utterly badass. The rocking soundtrack that picks up at the most epic moments make you feel like a total action hero and the fighting system combined with bullet-time make this an utter hoot to play. I owned and played the full length game on the 360 and I ahve to say this DLC version is superior by far. Hop in, stomp some darkness and rock on!


Note: This is not a full-length game, as it was made to be an add-on to the original, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is it fun while it lasts.

reviewText:
An improvement over the original game's double-DLC epilogue that, despite ending great-ish, left me with mixed feelin's. AN's story as it relates to AW boggled the mind, but it's still damn good in the realm of video games; more self-aware flirtations with storytelling tropes, this time more thoroughly entrenched in AW's schlocky influences.

The story's 'bout half the length of AW's, but feels far shorter due to the limited scope & # of explorable environments. 3 maps, each repeated 3 times in a time loop. I tend to hate time loop stories, but this one left a mostly pos. impression. It's reasoning is believable in the context of the story, but that doesn't stop it from occas. feeling like a sad excuse to lengthen the game. (I love the changes b/w repeats, e.g., NPCs recognizing you and starting to understand their places in the loop--esp. the scientist's 4th-wall commentary on being unable to remember anything outside of her purpose in Wake's story.)

Out of room. Solid continuation.

Love this series.  Highly recommended to anyone who likes survival type games.

It has been quite a while since i played Alan Wake.  Playing this one, brought back the old feeling and made me reinstall the original version, which is way better.

Still i enjoyed this one a lot too.  Alan's evil side is truly twisted! Adding the arcade mode is a very nice touch, but it is not really my playstyle, so I did not really look into it.  It will take you a good evening, maybe 2, to finish the main storyline.

It has a high replay value, specially  if you want to make all achievements and find all goodies, like radio and tv shows.
And even more if you are into arcade mode.

Loved playing it! Again thsi eery atmosphere that makes your skin crawl.  I did find this one way easier as the original Alan wake  (specially in nightmare mode;)

A fantastic addition to the series! They take a lot of the strengths from the first game and keep them in place, but they also take a bunch of the weaknesses as well and greatly improve them. In comparison, this game is much easier than Alan Wake but I had so much fun playing it the difficulty nerf didn't really bother me. Finally there is a larger selection of weapons, but to be honest my favorites ended up being the standard issue 9mm pistol, and the crossbow, together they got the job done clean and quickly. If you are familiar with the predecessor to this game, the flash bangs and flare gun have been nerfed as well, but with a decent amount of balance. Ammo conservation isn't nearly as pertinent in this edition with the abundant and refilling ammo caches in each zone. Exploring isn't nearly as nerve racking or dangerous as well, which is a bit of a letdown.

********ATTENTION: POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD********

The story of this game is solid, but also unoriginal. The whole idea of a repeating day has been done a lot, but it somewhat fits in with the setting of Night Springs that the game presents. Still not 100% sure if this is just another episode, or if it actually happened. Either way, the change of setting is very welcomed and the new enemies are a nice addition. I do enjoy the idea of dealing with a doppelganger though, and Mr Scratch pulls it off VERY well, I actually really like the guy.

********END OF POSSIBLE SPOILERS********

As for rating, on an enjoyment level I would give this game a solid 8.5 / 10 if you are just in it for how fun the game is. If you want to be a stickler and rate the actual level of design and originality in the game, it would have to be a 7 / 10. Either way, this is still a damn good game, especially if you played Alan Wake.

Alan Wake's American Nightmare is a good game, if you take into account the price. It only costs $10, before any potential sale, and if you like the original Alan Wake, then it is worth picking up. It's not perfect. There are only three levels that you repeat three times each due to time travel effects. However, there's enough variety in enemies and weapons that it is still worth your money and time.

If you haven't played Alan Wake, you might actually enjoy this, but won't really understand what's happening plot-wise, if you have played Alan Wake, you should definitely pick this up because it fixes a lot of the mechanics from the main game and adds more to the Alan Wake storyline.

This was released as DLC to the main game but it works as a stand alone title, and I believe it was originally meant to be a complete sequel but they only got funded for this size project.

If you enjoyed Alan Wake, but disliked the flashlight and shooting mechanics, you'll really appreciate this as the gunplay and combat is vastly improved. The enemy types are similar to the last game, and although they follow the same formula of flashlight-stun-shoot they have different abilities and appearances.

This game is set in the Arizona desert as opposed to the last games lush Pacific Northwest forests. The setting makes for a nice change of pace, and the big open landscape is really beneficial to the combat and exploration in my opinion. Also, whereas the last game took a lot of cues from American horror literature... and Twin Peaks. This game takes more cues from American horror films, and television, specifically the Twilight Zone, and it's very well off for it.

The story doesn't do as much as I would like in continuing the storyline from the first game but is still fairly interesting on it's own as it gives glimpses into what's going on in the real world."  I think the developers wanted to do more in that regard
date: but held back because they're still hoping to do a proper sequel at some point.\n\nFinally

reviewText:
American Nightmare is quite different from it's predecessor in crucial points and not always for the best. Therefor, the pros and cons rely a lot on comparison with Alan Wake.

Pros:
+ Collecting manuscrpit pages now has a clear benefit that was absent in it's predecessor.
+ New cool enemies.
+ Intelligent AI, the enemies try to surround you whenever possible.
+ Loot and pick-ups are well marked.
+ Plenty of ammo.
+ Open world.
+ Battery change is quicker than in Alan Wake.
+ Usage of real actors in cut scenes.

Cons:
- From visual point of view it's a step back from Alan Wake.
- This sequel feels more like a game. It's predecessor had such a high standard of realism that it felt more life-like.
- The graphics are worse than in Alan Wake.
- Bad dialogues.
- Bad characters and voiceover.
- Feels like it was done before the main game.
- You couldn't choose weather you wanted to leave an area.
- Switching weapons is hard in the middle of a battle.
- Less atmosphere = enemies weren't that scary.
- I thought there'd be a final battle thing, it never came.

Verdict:
American Nightmare often felt raw, it's state of completion rushed. Several of the choices that the developers made leave you thinking what they had in mind. So, it's not the Alan Wake you think you'd get after what they had done previously. Nevertheless I recommend it, after all we are talking about an Alan Wake game.

I'm a huge fan of the Alan Wake universe and the lore Sam Lake/Remedy created with the first game, so of course I absolutely loved American Nightmare. Being quicker paced and more action packed with a large variety of weapons, including a nail gun and assault rifle, American Nightmare is a pulp fiction video game galore. It's pulp fiction because of how it's told, the narrative is that Alan Wake wrote himself into an episode of Night Springs just so he can slip into reality from the darkness and kill Mr. Scratch, the doppleganger that appears at the end of Alan Wake.

I absolutely love the art style Remedy approached when recreating a sort of desert town in Arizona, the canyons, cacti, shrubs, and red rocks really stand out. Textures could be higher quality, but originally being an XBLA game, I'm assuming they had to consolidate the sizes. A shame they didn't go all out on the PC port though. Another thing I enjoyed was the semi-open world they layed out. The game is split into three areas, the Motel area, Observation tower area, and the drive-in theater. Each of the levels are rather small, but open enough that you can explore to find the manuscript pages and take in the details.

Basically, I really liked this game. It could have been longer, and the textures could have been higher quality, but I understand that they weren't able to make American Nightmare a full game as Microsoft wanted Remedy to start working on the upcoming Quantum Break, which I hope comes to PC. The ending of Nightmare leaves me wanting more though, I need to find out what happens to Alan Wake. I just hope Remedy makes the long awaited sequel some day.

9.0/10

The game takes at most 3 hours to complete. It is not worth even those few dollars it costs. It is an obvious attempt to capitalize on the original title without putting any effort in it whatsoever. Alan Wake's American Nightmare is basically 3 small levels repeated 3 times with a new type of enemy introduced in each iteration. And the story's main point is to justify taking you through exactly the same levels 3 times. So strictly speaking it is not even 3 hours of gameplay, but rather around 40 minutes.

reviewText:
Its sort of a little adjunct story to the main Alan Wake tale.  They fix some of the nagging combat issues from the main game with a hammer called uzi, and that can be kind of fun... but... its one of those tradeoffs where there may be plenty of survival, but is there really that much horror when you have assault rifles and mag fed 9mm pistols etc? There was something (albeit admittedly something frustrating) to be said for the tension of frantically hand loading individual revolver rounds as the shadows closed in on you.

Where as the main game you slogged through the combat for the story, this almost takes the opposite approach... they spice up the combat but the story is a little less... riveting.  Its not terrible, its just not going to live up to the main game there.

All in all its a decent little diversion for Alan Wake fans, but I wouldn't chalk it up as a must play.

(7/10)

reviewText: Alan Wake's American Nightmare (AWAN) is an indirect sequel to the original Alan Wake video game. Maintaining its third-person shooter perspective, AWAN does lose sight of its psychological horror/thriller aspect in exchange for a more action-packed thrill ride. The game features a loose plot, but still contributes to the greater story of the Alan Wake series. If you enjoyed the first game and you're anxious to experience more of Alan Wake's unique combat, then AWAN is just for you!

reviewText:
Alan Wake's American Nightmare offers an exaggerated pulp action adventure where the horrors of reality come to true.
Alan Wake finds himself stuck in an altered reality filled with dangerous shadows and he must Mr. Scratch, Wake's evil doppelganger who's supernatural serial killer. To end the darkness and defeat Scratch, Alan Wake must learn to control reality along with the power of light.
The story is quite intriguing, the graphics are pretty good and the gameplay feels more dynamic when compared to Alan Wake's original game.
Although Alan Wake's American Nightmare is more of a DLC than an actual game, I recommend it and it definitely provides a great experience.

reviewText:
Alan Wake's American Nightmare is the 2nd game in the Alan Wake franchise. Although it is a standalone product on Steam, it plays more like an expansion pack to Alan Wake than a direct sequel. The story is shorter and far less compelling, but the action, gameplay, and graphics are all beefed up a bit and actually a lot more fun than Alan Wake.

The Good:

* Low price tag, the game is $10 base and frequently goes for $5 during Steam sales.

* Rather than walking down a hallway with the occasional monster (which is the original Alan Wake in a nutshell), American Nightmare features a more open-world. That being said, the game-world is incredibly small and features only three locales: a rest stop, an observatory, and drive-in theatre.

The Bad:

* The arcade mode, which is supposed to be one of the main draws of this game, is flat and not fun. It's very similar to Resident Evil's Mercenaries" mode
date: where you simply run around and try to kill monsters in combos. However
recommended:
Resident Evil somehow manages to be more fun and feel faster-paced.

* Some art objects were taken directly from the original Alan Wake and stand out.

The Ugly:

* Being from Arizona
voteText: there were way too many noticeable errors. We don't have license plates on the front of our cars. There are Saguaro Cactuses in our deserts. There are not tall deciduous trees. I understand the location is a fictional town created in Alan's head
helpfulPercent:
but I really don't care. I choose to be outraged!

The Verdict:

American Nightmare is short and sweet
votesHelpful: and fixes almost everything that was wrong with the original Alan Wake. Since most people buy both games together
votesTotal: I kept this review short. However
votesFunny: if you have to pick one of the two
commentsCount: I would definitely tell you to get American Nightmare. Keep in mind
column16: though
column17: that American Nightmare does NOT compare to many other AAA shooter titles - it is fairly generic and won't offer you a revolutionary experience."

reviewText:
Alan Wake's American Nightmare deserve a 62% grade on its manuscript (62/100)

Alan Wake's American Nightmare can either be the dream story your want to play through the hellish nightmare it can be at times. Alan Wake takes you again on the story of Alan's Wake TV as you have to rewrite the world, over, and over, and unfortunately, over again. The game itself is amazing and excels, and falls, in the story. I would highly recommend you play this game, its short, it catches you and, it has one of the best stories in video games I've ever played.

Story: 7/10
+Remedy always knows how to tell a story, the story is amazing
+Do not need to play Alan Wake to understand Alan Wake's American Nightmare
+Characters are believable and Matthew Porretta did amazing job as Alan Wake
+The ending is touching and worth the game
-The story is repetitive though, as you get sent back to the beginning by your evil version back and you must rewrite the story over and over and over again till you get EVERYTHING right which is its biggest fault

Environment: 7/10
+Beautifully designed and great detail
+Dark atmosphere with limited light matches the game SO WELL
+From the cafe to the observatory to the drive in, everything is beautifully designed
+Though the game is linear, it does allow A LOT of exploration in each level and actually kinda recommends it as you get better weapons, you must find manuscripts and to go deeper in the story, you must find TVs where your evil self recommended himself
-Felt like this game would have been better as an open world game though

Controls: 10/10
+Controller enabled
+Fluent and comfortable, works well, no complaints
+Recommend playing with controller

Gameplay: 7/10
+Combat is amazing, so beautifully done
+Ammo is just perfect where you will run out of ammo for one or two gun(s), but not all
+Added a survival mode with perfectly designed maps
-[SPOILER Final battle was... too easy for how climatic it was]

Multiplayer: 0/10
-None
-This game would have been amazing if it had a co-op for its multiplayer
-Seriously? Not even local

reviewText:
Alan Wake's American Nightmare can be considered a short sequel to the first Alan Wake game as it picks up directly after The Signal and The Writer episodes.
In general, the shooting mechanics and movement feel more crisp and smooth, there is an expanded variety of weapons to use, although most of them function similarly. (Mainly being: High Damage Single Shot, Low Damage Machine Gun or High Damage Shotgun Shot)
In the first game, Flashbangs and Flare Guns used to be the ultimate weapons as they can easily clear all enemies in an area. This is not the case in the sequel. They are only able to take out some weak enemies while their main function is to disable enemies and clear off the darkness.

The story component is short, about 1/3 the length of the original Alan Wake.
However, there is a Arcade mode which puts you in 5 distinct settings and challenges you to score as many points as possible through defeating enemies and maintaining your streak by avoiding damage.

If you enjoyed Alan Wake, this sequel is great fun. Just take your time to explore the areas and listen to the dialogue for a more detailed understanding of Alan Wake's world.
If you did not enjoy Alan Wake, this sequel will not interest you much unless you would really love to try out the improved shooting mechanics and the new enemy types.
If you are thinking about playing either, Alan Wake is a better introduction to the series.

My review of Alan Wake can be found here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/fenghuang/recommended/108710/

reviewText: Loved Alan Wake, but this expansion/sequel is bad.  They turned the game into an action shooter.  You run around levels killing the same enemies over and over and over.  The story and characters you meet are mostly forgetable, as are the set pieces.  You are never in any danger, as you will never run out of ammo since they have multiple infinite ammo spots on each level.  You play through 3 levels, and then you play through those same 3 levels again, and then you play through those same 3 levels again before the game finally ends.  Hope you enjoy those 3 levels, because you get to see a lot of them.  There are very few new or interesting enemies and by the end of the game you'll be tired of killing them over and over again, especially since they pose almost no threat to you.  Do yourself a favor and never play this garbage.

reviewText: The first game in this series was atmospheric, could make you think, make you laugh, and could at times be genuinely scary. With a grade A soundtrack which used actual artists and made its own music, you had a solid game. Was it perfect? No, certain graphics were a little wonky and there was pretty bad product placement, but it was a game I’d suggest to friends and people who enjoyed the genre of adventure/horror. The sequel on the other hand took all that was good and sort of tosses it away. Making it more of a battle game than anything else. If you're looking for that, you'll be fine. If you're looking for more of the first game though, you will be disappointed.

reviewText: The American nightmare picks up a couple of years after the events of the first game. Alan is still trapped in limbo - in the dark place, but evidently some parts of his mind attempt to escape the hold of the darkness. When he was first touched by darkness he spawned Mr. Scratch - an evil but charismatic,enigmatic as well as a better" version of himself as Mr. Scratch himself put it.\n\nMr. Scratch is trying to get out into the world and replace Wake who is thought dead by everyone except Barry. Wake finds himself in Arizona where weird phenomena keeps happening. He finds himself in a horror episode created by Mr. Scratch. ok
date: no more spoilers but there are a couple of twists in the story
recommended: and then there are more...twists..again and again....\n\nThere are only three more characters in the game so it feels pretty desolate. Pretty soon the game turns into an arcade shoot. The ammo is plentiful (there are actually ammo and supply respawns throughout the game)
hoursPlayed: the open-worldliness of the first map kinda takes away the feeling of accomplishment. You keep looking for the pages of the manuscript that Wake keeps writing in the dark place and use it to unlock better weapons as well as knowledge about what to do next.\n\nThere are about 5 new enemies. There are spiders
voteText: there are those who can split into multiple versions of themselves
helpfulPercent: those who can stand 9 feet tall and wild large chain saws
votesHelpful: those who turn into birds and those who can throw stink bombs
votesTotal:
I guess.

What's interesting is how you are able to pick up on the events of the world through radio shows and disturbing camcorder videos done by Mr. Scratch which were an absolute blast to watch and there are plenty of them. They used plenty of live video here which is unheard of in 99% of games. I also particularly enjoyed the determinism vs. free will arguments between Wake and the astronomer as well as on the radio. Wake basically argued that the absence of free will is irrelevant given the fact that the character knows nothing about the next set of set deterministic events.

In any case the atmosphere is there
votesFunny: but it also feels kind of cheap
commentsCount:
the desert is just too boring. I also found myself disinterested for the first couple of hours but then I kept playing and kept getting sucked in. It took me about 5.5 hours to finish the game. The game also does a pretty good job of explaining why the first game looked [played] like a TV show or a drama/thriller movie. Wake explains that he is able to fight the Taken effectively (and dodge attacks) because that was a small semi-realistic kernel of the main protagonist that helps propel the story forward. So many more things can make sense now for those who didn't really get the original game.

There is also a survival mode. You are given 10 minutes to fight off the taken at various locations until the sunrise. It can be fun but I doubt you will be playing it more than a few times. I put the game into the hard category because there are a few frustrating spots in the game (especially the last 20 minutes) but you do feel pretty good when you survive multiple attacks with the last few bullets.

All in all. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoyed the first game."

reviewText:
Pretty good followup to Alan Wake. I finished it with all the collectables within 6 hours, but enjoyed all of it. The game retains the same combat mechanics as the first title, and throws in a few new refreshing additions, such as new weapons, new enemies, and a different style of boss fights.

Just like the first game, the storytelling is strong. This time, live action is used more heavily. All the cutscenes are done surprisingly well in live action, and there are a lot more ingame tv bits of Alan talking crazy. The cutscenes and Alan's dialogue/manuscript readings are great to listen to. The game is much shorter this time around with only three levels, which cleverly repeat themselves over the course of 3 Acts. There is also an Arcade mode apart form the main Story mode. It resembles a typical survival mode of some zombie killing game. You can avoid it.

Overall, another good game by Remedy. It's a nice short extension to the Alan Wake storyline if you feel you need more of it after beating the first.

reviewText: Building upon the foundations of the original Alan Wake; American Nightmare removes you from the shady forests and logtree cabins of Bright Falls and places you somewhere in dusty Arizona on the hunt for your evil doppleganger 'Mr.Scratch'. Alan Wake's American Nightmare gets things right as much as it does wrong with regards to gameplay; finally you are moved to an open world area to explore at your leisure, places to see and weapons to unlock via acquisition of manuscript pages; its a disappointment that the missions themselves aren't quite so enthralling as you'll find yourself running back and forth through recycled set pieces that subtract from an otherwise enjoyable story experience.

reviewText: A game in the same series as Alan Wake but isn't a real sequel, more of a little short story inside of the game. You are told in the beginning of the game that basically nothing that happens in this game actually happened to Alan Wake. It is a short story written by Alan Wake for the show Night Springs. The game is about Alan Wake trying to defeat his crazy doppleganger Mr. Scratch who goes around and murders people for fun. Alan has to get manuscript pages to complete the scenes and then destroy Mr. Scratch. The gameplay is not quite as fun as it was in Alan Wake because it was more frequent and a felt a little more scripted and expected than the original. The amount of guns was good and the exploration was still good. The graphics aren't as good as Alan Wake and this game just overall wasn't as good. Don't get me wrong it is still great just a little on the disappointing side for me. I still recommend this game to anyone who likes thriller/horror games with an interesting story. 75/100

reviewText:
This was a decent sequel to the really great original Alan Wake game.

However, this game was fairly short in compares (finished with all non-arcade achievements in 6 hours, while the original took me 35?). It was much easier overall, and only had a few locations. This could have very well been simply another DLC for the main game. Unsure why they bothered making this a stand alone. Because clearly if you did not play the original, you would be almost entirely lost on the whole story.

The thing I did not care for, is they threw in this 'Arcade Mode' thing as like some sort of last ditch effort to make it worth a stand alone price. It serves no purpose, is extremely boring, and well... wasn't needed.

Overall, if you can grab this on sale, its worth it if you liked the original Alan Wake game. If you never played the original game... do not bother with this as you will be lost, and left with a empty feeling and buyers remorse.

reviewText:
Pretty good followup to Alan Wake. I finished it with all the collectables within 6 hours, but enjoyed all of it. The game retains the same combat mechanics as the first title, and throws in a few new refreshing additions, such as new weapons, new enemies, and a different style of boss fights.

Just like the first game, the storytelling is strong. This time, live action is used more heavily. All the cutscenes are done surprisingly well in live action, and there are a lot more ingame tv bits of Alan talking crazy. The cutscenes and Alan's dialogue/manuscript readings are great to listen to. The game is much shorter this time around with only three levels, which cleverly repeat themselves over the course of 3 Acts. There is also an Arcade mode apart form the main Story mode. It resembles a typical survival mode of some zombie killing game. You can avoid it.

Overall, another good game by Remedy. It's a nice short extension to the Alan Wake storyline if you feel you need more of it after beating the first.

reviewText: A game in the same series as Alan Wake but isn't a real sequel, more of a little short story inside of the game. You are told in the beginning of the game that basically nothing that happens in this game actually happened to Alan Wake. It is a short story written by Alan Wake for the show Night Springs. The game is about Alan Wake trying to defeat his crazy doppleganger Mr. Scratch who goes around and murders people for fun. reviewText:
I got this game as a casual gamer, in a package with the first Alan Wake. Gotta admit, I found the first Alan wake too hard for me. But I got a Steam Controller for Christmas and it works so great with American Nightmare!

As a casual gamer I just played story mode on normal level. but this game has a lot of variation for people who wanna kick it up a notch with nightmare mode and arcade mode.

The graphics and voice acting were awesome. I found the actual gameplay much easier than the first one in terms of port. Movements were better, shooting was better, and just the overall controls were much better. I really can't say enough about how well it worked with the steam controller.

The cut scenes weren't too long, and the story was interesting... picking right up where Alan Wake left off. You don't have to have played the first game, the entire thing is on youtube if you wanted to watch the cut scenes so you know the story.

I did find it a bit repetative story wise. I was hoping for a longer scene after the end credits. The final boss battle was actually one of the easier battles of the game.

As opposed to the first one where you could get stuck in a loop where you restart a checkpoint but have no ammo or batteries, this game made sure there were plenty of opprotunities to get what you needed.

I found it interesting that most of the supporting characters were women, was kinda hoping to see some of the characters from the first Alan Wake.

I took me a while to beat, I'm sure more competant gamers could beat it faster and enjoy unlocking all the achievments. Good replay value.

reviewText:
As Alien is more of a horror to Aliens and how that is more action focused is the difference between this one and the previous game. It's not a fear-filled game and certainly doesn't build up atmostphere like the last one as you are thrust into the action, however that doesn't mean it's bad. The story is very good and it gives a happy ending to it too.

The improvements I like is that you have a mini map to tell you where the manuscripts are, making the achievement to get them all insultingly easy, which is a good thing in my opinion.

Also, collecting the manuscripts gives you an advantage. The more you collect the more weapons you can unlock which can help cut the enemies down. Free tip, Crossbow is the best damn weapon. It destroys the darkness surrounding the Taken and for most Taken it's a one-hit kill.

The creatures in this are a lot more creative. You have some that don't have protection, but instead split and these creepy spider-like creatures. Clearly here the people were being more creative with the monsters and it's very well recieved and Mr. Scratch makes a very good villain. If you liked the first game, you'll love this one too, but it is more action based than storline I'm afraid, as you can tell from the many achievements revolving around the arcade mode.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It would be hard for me to talk about American Nightmare without touching on the original Alan Wake, because it very much feels like DLC that got spun into its own game. Alan Wake's strengths were its story, pacing, and graphics. The combat was a bit of a toss-up between decent and monotonous, depending on who you asked. American Nightmare is a shorter, weirder story told across three mostly open areas that you visit multiple times. The visuals are still sharp, but lose a lot of the atmosphere that Alan Wake had... the open desert just doesn't have the same creep factor as the dark woods, at least not as it's shown here. Dialogue is pretty snappy and clever, but it's propping up a story that really adds nothing to the themes introduced in Alan Wake.

So the main draw is the combat, and to its credit, it's a little more interesting than in Alan Wake. Enemy encounters are varied in makeup, and there are some new foes like ones that split if you shine light on them and creepy jumping spider things. All the original weapons are here, along with new additions like a nailgun, uzi, and carbine. You can unlock weapon cases with additional weapons by finding manuscript pages scattered around which encourages exploration, but honestly as large as the areas are, there's not much to find. Enemies only appear as you follow the main plot, and the game showers you with ammo and flare, more than enough to handle any situation. I tried playing on the harder of the two difficulties and the battles were still a breeze with all the resources I had, but I could be killed in just two hits which led to some frustration with unlucky hits at the ends of long fights.

There's an arcade mode similar to the mercenaries modes in Resident Evil that's pretty fun, assuming you like the combat. And that's really what American Nightmare boils down to, did you like the combat in Alan Wake? If so, this is for you, but don't come looking for the atmosphere or story of the original.

reviewText:
Alan Wake's American Nightmare follows the adventures of Alan Wake as he attempts to chase down and thwart the schemes of his mysterious double by rewriting reality. As interesting as this may sound, the premise is ultimately let down by shallow combat and uninspired environments. In a story which seems so incredibly bizarre at first glance, it is a shame that the game which surrounds it is so average.

Alan Wake's American Nightmare markets itself as a third person horror game, but fails to differentiate its self from other games in its genre. It's combat, While not bad, will seem very familiar to anyone who has spent any amount of time playing similar games. Ammo is plentiful and combat is relatively easy as a result. Most of the weapons available feel familiar as well, with basic pistols, rifles and shotguns making up the bulk of your arsenal. Only the occasional power tool manages to change up the stagnant weapon variety, but such weapons are too few and far between. Another minor way in which Alan Wake's American Nightmare tries to differentiate itself from its peers is through its use of the flashlight. Before an enemy will be vulnerable to attacks, they must be exposed to light for a period of time, either with a flashlight or other means. This creates some welcome tension, as the player tries to juggle foes with their flashlight, all while watching their batteries slowly drain. Unfortunately, doing so can become cumbersome in later sections of the game as the quantity of enemies being thrown at the player increases.

I was also alarmed to discover that despite Alan Wake's American Nightmare's short length, it still managed to recycle most of it's environments multiple times. I don't believe that recycling environments is always a bad thing as long as they are sufficiently altered to create new and unique game-play experiences, but in this case I just felt as though the recycled spaces were their to serve as padding.

While by no means a terrible game, Alan Wake's American Nightmare feels far too familiar. Throughout the experience I couldn't help but feel that my time would be better spent elsewhere. For people who are interested it may still be worth giving a shot, but don't expect anything amazing.

reviewText: This game had some really good ideas. A flashlight that recharges faster, and more streamlined weapons, ammo and dodge mechanics. However, the problem with the game is that it recycles the same some 3-4 stages over and over and over again. Once you think you beat the Arizona areas, the game puts you right back at the beginning of stage one all over again saying that something else has happened there. This is a cheap way to increase game time and easily becomes boring as very few to no new elements get introduced after this point, you are literally put in a loop. It might be that this is the game's vision but this pretentious ideology only saves the creators the time of actually creating more good ideas and locations that would make the story actually interesting.  I lament this fact because the game has really good functionality that is better in the first game, but throws it all away by literally reusing the same locations over and over and over again. DO NOT buy this game, instead, if you haven't already buy the first Alan Wake game instead.

reviewText:
Short and sharp. Fantastic little game that will only take you 2-3 hours to complete, but oh boy is it a great story. Without spoiling anything I will say that you revisit the same places a few times over and over, but each time you do, the circumstances are vastly different which really makes you interested to keep going through the story to see what they are.

Presentation: 9/10 - The game comes together nicely. I couldn't really tell you what it was missing because there wasn't really anything. Storyline really draws you in, it is put together flawlessly.

Graphics: 8.5/10 - Left only a little to be desired. It has a really nice atmosphere and the game felt creepy a lot of the time because of it.

Sound: 9/10 - The shooting is great, the music is eery and the music score is excellent.

Gameplay: 8.5/10 - I really enjoyed the shooting and how your torch is a weapon. There are some really fantastic moments in this game that will have you going, Damn
date: that was cool."\n\nLasting Appeal: 6/10 - Not really any reason to repeat this game
recommended: but that doesn't matter. Get it for a great story and for the thrill."

reviewText: This game is decent but nothing I myself would rave about. I played the first Alan Wake and remember they combat and weapons and story. This game is good with graphics and is a solid familiar feel to the old version but certainly isn't as pleasing. This game features more weapons which i believe is one of the greatest downfalls of the game. I mean the reward of collecting pages for a better weapon is okay but i believe could of been integrated in a different way.  This game was way to easy to complete and the mechanics babied you too much the entire time. On my first playthrough i beat the game in 3.5 hours and collected 40 out of the 53 pages. The mini map even had minor indicators for the pages you search for; which tells me that the pages truely aren't hidden. Your suppose to work for the pages not be lead to them. With this said the unlockable weapons will range from a scale of VERY underpowered or SUPER overpowered. To me the characters are crap for realism. Alan wake is a Writer not a soldier and somehow he knows how to perfectly use an assault rifle? The character even admits it himself in the first game he never used a gun for a long period of time if at all. The mechanics of the revolvers, shotguns and a bolt action rifle are easy to learn by looking at them. But military grade weapons are much to complex to use like a pro the first shot. With this said your magical ability to use each weapon like a master and reload them withen seconds is what makes the game far too easy. The story was meh but good if you get it on sale for a time killer. i paid 99cents .  I say content was extremely lacking and this game feels more like a special dlc for the game.  I say this game is worth one playthrough if your a fan of Alan wake but other then that this game is definitely not worth full price. wait for a holiday sale . With all this said i must add that the first game had a stronger feel of lonely helplessness while here you feel like your able to fully help yourself with no big issue. but would i reccomend this that would be a no.

reviewText:
I only suggest that you buy this game if you get it 80% off in a bundle with the first one. Or if you already have beaten the first one and want more story explained (but even then, its not worth 10 bucks!!) And btw i didnt even bother playing the Arcade part of the game, this is just a review of the capaign portion.

Here are the problems that i have with this game:
- The suspence/horror aspect that we all loved from Alan Wake is completely gone. Think of the progression from Dead Space 1 to Dead Space 3, except Dead Space 3 made up for it cuz it was far more epic. This game is more tailored to an action adventure, and it hardly feels like Alan Wake anymore
- This game supplies you with the closest thing to unlimited ammo i have ever seen. Its absolutely ridiculous. Dont even bother conserving ammo and batteries because you will NEVER run out. The result of this ammo surplus makes the game completely unintimidating.
- The man who played Alan Wakes Doppelganger persona was a TERRIBLE ACTOR. It might not bother you, but i wanted to gouge my eyes out when you tune into his monologues on the TVs because of how god awful his attempt to be insane and evil was.
- THE REPETITION. Its so incredibly repetative that i have no desire to focus 70% of the time playing.
- Throughout the game there are a total of 3 moments when there would be battle music" of some kind to add to the "epicness" of the situation and 2 out of 3 of the songs were terrible. One was some extremely cheesy 1980's heavy metal track with bad vocals and terribly guitar solos and the other was just stupid ("IM A PSYCHO BABY

reviewText:
Alan Wake's American Nightmare is one of the most atmospheric and immersive video games I've ever played. The story is a dark, twisted, sinister-like fantasy all wrapped up in a strong narrative by yours truly, The Champion of Light, Alan Wake.

To tell you a little bit about the developer, Remedy, they brought us the classic video games like Max Payne 1 and 2. Inventive storytelling, with a dark tonality. Alan Wake's American Nightmare might not pose any scares like the original Alan Wake, but it's such a well-polished PC port that I can't help but acknowledge Remedy for doing such a wonderful job.

The graphics feature high-resolution, and high-res textures, making the Xbox 360 version pale in comparison. I remember vividly playing the original Alan Wake on the Xbox 360 and the difference is like night and day. Although, I have no regrets about buying the original Alan Wake on the Xbox 360 because it went towards supporting such a great developer, and now we have American Nightmare. The visuals are clean and crisp. I think I took over 100 screenshots in my first 2-3 hours of gameplay. I couldn't help but stop to look at the surroundings and environments. The lighting and shadows are incredible. It's a beautiful game.

Excellent story, narrative, atmosphere, immersion, and being one of the top 10 best PC-ported video games on the planet, American Nightmare stretches to a 6-7 hour standalone game for a mere price of $5-10 on a good sale. It's totally worth that much and more.

Despite these bright features, American Nightmare is flawed by being too easy on the difficulty side. The game loses all tension on Normal mode, and it is best played on Nightmare mode instead. On Normal mode, there are ample ammo and weapons throughout the environments and fighting enemies is way too simplified and easy. Enemies do not even get close to you with the high amount of arsenal and flares at your disposal. But if you're just looking for an atmospheric experience without the challenge, then Normal mode is perfectly suitable for a playthrough.

If you thoroughly enjoyed the original Alan Wake, and you want more of pursue more of the atmospheric-story-driven game, look no further. Turn the lights off, put on your headphones, and drift away into the darkness.

Rating: 8 out of 10

Alan wake capitalist horror story is one of the worst follow ups to a stellar game i've played in years, the story blows, the new characters blow, the voice acting blows, the animation in cut scenes blow, the new enemy's are meh, the new guns are weird and some are useless, the flash grenades were weakened, the ending is horrid, the live actor scenes are awkward, the villain is horrible and non of the games cunning ideas are properly executed. reviewText:
Previously impressed with the intricate story-line, plot and themes from Alan Wake, I was anxious to get my hands on its stand-alone addition, Alan Wake’s American Nightmare. While American Nightmare takes aim at correcting many shortcomings from the original game, such as the horrid combat system, it felt as if it was missing much more.

As stated, American Nightmare supplies Alan with a greater arsenal and enhanced combat system much lacking in the first game. Unfortunately, American Nightmare steers away from the captivating storyline and supplies the gamer with a plot that is more reminiscent of an afterthought or pages of the original script that arguably, should have been left in the waste bin.

Featuring unusual level lay-out I can't explicitly describe without a spoiler, I can say it seems very much a cop out. At times I felt frustrated enough to mutter to myself, “If this keeps going on like this… I’m going to stop playing.” American Nightmare comes across less as an excellent addition to a thought provoking game, and more of an over-hyped, contractually obligated DLC. I would only recommend if you can find on sale, and were a huge fan of the original game and really feel the need to lick Remedy Game’s plate clean.

reviewText:
As a writer, I consider the first Alan Wake a great game for its metalinguistic. The story within the story, the topic of what makes a writer a writer, the symbolism of the dark force as the market and the stupid corporate suits who twist and turn the will of an artist to make raw money... The fact that the story unfolded in two fronts (the game and the pages you collected) was specially fascinating.

As a gamer, the first Alan wake was interesting, nothing special beyond the light mechanic but fun on its own way, I ended up annoyed because even in the nightmare, the enemies were merely annoying and there was too much ammo (and with my hoarder mentality from games like Resident Evil and Dead Space, I ended having lots of moments where I left crates of ammo behind because I was full).

But this... unfortunately... feels like a shoddy and lazy filler. There is no story, it's just Alan hunting his doppleganger that it's in his place because story reasons that aren't really explained, the same places are used over and over and over. The city that the developers made with care to look alive and real is replaced by three patches of boring desert with three female characters that are awfully and lazily voiced. The combat has been dumbed down (amazingly), even if there are more guns for you to use, you can only carry two: A main arm, and a sidearm.

But sir! Alan Wake was supposed to be realistic! The devs said so! You don't see a guy carrying fifteen weapons on his pockets!" Yeah

reviewText:
American Nightmare is an interesting addition to a superb third-person shooter. The location now is Arizona; instead of dark woods you now have desert-like areas and the game focuses on a very arcade-like shooting experience.

Beside the plot - which is the continuation of the original - you have stages you can play separately and as there are leaderboards you can replay them for higher score.

I recommend this expansion pack but only if it's on sale, otherwise it's just too short and isn't worth the money. While the arcade like features are nice I missed the long and interesting story that characterised the vanilla game. For me American Nightmare was fun but a bit of a let down after the core game and its DLCs.

reviewText: American Nightmare represents an epilogue to the main Alan Wake game, and as such it would be best to complete that story first.  Alan finds himself stuck" in a new reality taunted by his evil doppleganger
date: whom he must eventually destroy to escape back to his wife in the "normal" world... where 2 years have passed and everyone believes Alan dead.  Again-another great idea
recommended: but the execution feels quite tedious.  The world is more open now and there is a map to guide you to your objectives.  the action mechanic of stunning and shooting the Taken is still present
hoursPlayed: although ammo and weapons are plentiful... I did not die once during the game on Normal.  There are manuscript pages
helpfulPercent: and radio shows to absorb if you have the patience to do so.  What killed it for me was the fact that you complete the same 3 maps and objectives 3 times!!  Granted
votesHelpful: each time the tasks are attenuated a bit
votesTotal: but there is nothing new to discover with subsequent iterations.  Bargain bin please."

reviewText:
Not as good as the first game.

The action elements are tigher and more satisfying, but the game feels rushed and low budget. The single player campaign has very few unique locations and has you doing what feels like a lot of backtracking to fill out for time. The story doesn't even add that much to the original game, I sort of feel like it even subtracts from it.

It has some special moments, including pretty much any of the videos of Mr. Scratch you can find in the game, but overall is really not a great buy.

Perhaps a lot more special if you can get friends together for the online co-op, but given that Alan Wake is already fairly niche, that seems like a daunting task at best.

I highly recommend the original game, but American Nightmare gets a pass.

reviewText: Ужас – это не когда кровь и кишки. Ужас – это когда начинаешь верить в то, что в темной комнате ты не единственное живое существо. Возможно, это и отличает качественную хоррор-литературу от дешевого ширпотреба, заполнившего в последние годы полки магазинов. Ведь чтобы напугать человека, нужно заставить его поверить в реальность нереального.\nПлюсы: интересный сюжет; полюбившийся всем герой; новые враги; более динамичные схватки; аркадный режим.\nМинусы: отсутствие кооператива в аркадном режиме; небольшая продолжительность; путешествие построено на неоднократном посещении одних и тех же локаций; некоторые враги вызывают недоумение (пауки!); не самый внятный финал.

reviewText:
Take it for what the game really is, a spinoff, expansion or whatever you want to call it.
It is very repetitive since you have to go back to the same places 3 times but i like it and i also like how things variate in the scenary everytime i go back. It still a fantastic experience like the first Alan Wake, if you liked the previous game i'm sure you will find it interesting and worth playing it.

Something that really loved about this was the Realtime cutscenes, god i hope they do the same with Alan Wake 2, and please i want more of The Old Gods Of Asgard.

Not so wonderful or epic as AW but well worth the money and a must buy..

My Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
American Nightmare is an interesting addition to a superb third-person shooter. The location now is Arizona; instead of dark woods you now have desert-like areas and the game focuses on a very arcade-like shooting experience.

Beside the plot - which is the continuation of the original - you have stages you can play separately and as there are leaderboards you can replay them for higher score.

I recommend this expansion pack but only if it's on sale, otherwise it's just too short and isn't worth the money. While the arcade like features are nice I missed the long and interesting story that characterised the vanilla game. For me American Nightmare was fun but a bit of a let down after the core game and its DLCs.

reviewText:
If I was enthusiastic about Alan Wake, the second opus American Nightmare is a major disappointment.

First of all, the game is mostly a shooter. You basically start with some arsenal, and get more powerful weapon as you go. Plus, there are boxes with ammuntion that auto-refills, thus loosing the pressure of  trying to get out the shooting as much as you can. Alan Wake turned badass is a bad idea.

Second, the game features only 3 maps, with the same characters and the same puzzles that you will play to death thanks to a time loop. Yep. The first time when you go back at your starting point, you ask yourself what you did wrong. Then the second time, you feel the game is just playing with you nerves and just want to finish it as soon as possible and forget it.

Really, Alan Wake's American Nightmare should be played only to see how an otherwise great licence can crash and burn due to unwise design choice.

reviewText:
I am an absolutely massive fan of Alan Wake; it's one of my favourite games of all time, I've finished it countless times on the Xbox 360, and I have a blast every time I play it. With that said, I found this standalone sequel to be rather disappointing in comparison to the brilliant first game; bear in mind that I do not think this is a bad game, it just falls rather falt and disappoints after the first game.
Alan Wake's American Nightmare is intended to play out as an episode of the fictional TV show called Night Springs, and is narrated by Lloyd Floyd, who provides an interesting narration to the story.The game has Alan Wake trapped in a sparse desert area, and who must find a way to escape the recurring nightmare he is stuck in.
And that leads to my first problem with the game; because Alan is stuck in a nightmare which repeats itself, you are forced to endure the same hour of gameplay THREE TIMES in a row until you finish this game. The exact same missions and locations, repeated three times. The first time is fun, the second time is kinda uninteresting, and the third time is downright boring and repetitive. This is a lazy way to repeat locations in a game, and it also reflects the poor writing skill of the writers.
The story is rather weird and disjointed. Throughout the entire game, you do a lot of things for unexplained reasons which aren't apparrently clear when you do them or even at the end of the game. The whole story is weird and quirky, but not in a good way, as it barely makes sense. The characters, apart from Alan and the absolutely BRILLIANT Mr Scratch, are boring and are just as quirky as the story itself. However, I found the live action cut scenes rather good, which was a surprise for me.
The gameplay is exactly the same as the first game, except that you can use new weapons like sub machine guns and nail guns. That's it. Zero changes made to the gameplay.
There's also a survival mode, which is actually quite fun. It's intense, challenging, and a fun way to compete on the leaderboards with your friends. I found this mode better than the campaign to be honest.
Overall, this is certainly not a bad game; it merely fails to innovate, and doesn't capture me the way the first game did. I still love Alan Wake, but this game disappointed me quite a bit. If you don't mind an extremely repetitive story, even with the game's shining parts, then pick t up for $3 on sale. 6 / 10.

reviewText: Alan Wake:American Nightmare is a spin-off to original game.You play as Alan Wake who is a writer and you must fight your way through darkness using light and firearms. While it’s not a direct sequel to previous game it still has same mechanics. But this time Remedy added more weapons making game more intense. While the main story is only 4 hours long it lacks good plot, and memorable characters. You just simply travel to 3 “Areas” 3 times and fight dark creatures to find some special objects to complete your mission in exact area. The atmosphere is great. It has gloomy backgrounds of Arizona which makes it look cool. Very awesome soundtrack to listen. You can also search for hidden manuscripts scattered all over the world which can be read later. They can give you some information about the lore of Alan Wake franchise. Finally new addition to game is Arcade mode. It’s basically “Horde Mode” just to kill waves of enemies till the dawn across 5 different maps.7/10

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Game has couple hours of new storyline connected to previous happenings
+ New insights and facts that you learn during these chapters make the whole picture clearer
+ The overall feels is still intact
+ Map that makes it a bit easier not to miss any of the script pages
+ Better gun choice to suit your style
+ New enemies but not much

Cons:
- Game makes you repeat stuff because of lack of new material to make a new game or even a decent DLC
- Locations are not that scary anymore
- Survival mode is not what original was about, it totally doesn't fit here, this game should stay within it's original formula
- Even if you like survival you won't find many maps or content there either...

So it looks like there's more pros than cons but I still give it a no, no. I was disappointed to see this game go the wrong direction. Hopefully this is just some kind of side game and the true successor to Alan Wake will be dedicated more to what made the original so great.

reviewText:
Really just awful.  The fact that this game has 'mostly positive' reviews really illustrates just how braindead your average person is.

First off, I actually kinda enjoyed Alan Wake.  It wasn't great by any stretch, but, whatever it had enough going on for me to finish the game which in itself says something.

But holy ♥♥♥♥, American Nightmare?  What a complete bore.  First off, the entire game is revisiting three setpieces over and over again.  There is zero challenge, thanks to the fact that all the ammo/weapons you could ever need are literally chucked all over the place so you don't even have to worry about being accurate when you mow through Taken.  The story is ridiculous and makes zero sense, and the voice acting is either mediocre or god-awful depending on who you're interacting with.

Took me 3 hours to get through, didn't die once, and had exactly zero fun the entire time.  Avoid like the plague.

reviewText:
HOUR COUNT: >20 on Xbox 360, 1.5 on PC

TL;DR: A nice little Xbox Live Arcade game, but not quite as good as the original game.  Also, it's a little short.  Arcade mode can add a lot of replayability.  If you're not sure, just pick it up on sale, preferrably as the Alan Wake Franchise so you can get the amazing first title.
--
Do I recommend it?  Only if you liked the first, or want the arcade mode.  Still rocking those fight-with-light mechanics, still fighting them darkness zambies, just more of the same-- which, trust me, isn't a bad thing!  It's a four to six hour standalone DLC campaign taking place after the events of the first game, and possibly the closest we'll ever get to a sequel (since Remedy's in deep ♥♥♥♥ and leaning on the success of Quantum Break).

I went ahead and took the game for a spin in arcade mode, and the port is excellent.  Easy 60 FPS with very few dips to 48 while maxed out at 1360x768, R9 280 and Pentium E6600 with 4GB of RAM.  32-bit users welcome.  Much less CPU-intensive than the original game, and much more optimized for 60 FPS.  Vsync can cause a few strange issues with mouse sensitivity, though.

The DLC campaign has about two hours of fresh new levels, then goes back to repeat itself three times.  Don't worry; you only cross over some of the centerpieces of each level, and you keep getting exposed to new parts of the levels you haven't visited before.  It's definitely a good campaign, and while it isn't on par with the original (as very few games are), it'll keep you playing for the duration.

Mechanically, it's good ol' Alan Wake.  The only change is that you can't just aim at them to burn their shields away.  This time, you HAVE to be boosting your flashlight (right-click) to wear down their shields... which makes combat a little more tense, since your magical shieldbreaker now has limited ammunition.  The dodging mechanic also seems to be a little more responsive, and enemies don't throw ♥♥♥♥ at you nearly as much.

Arcade mode was done well, though it could be better.  You start with a 9mm and flashlight, you have an ammo box that comes back every three minutes, a few lights to replenish your health, and you've got 10 minutes until sunrise.  There's also weapons around the map, and a few weapon cases that can only be opened if you collected x number of manuscript pages during the campaign.  You get tons of enemies thrown at you with several variations, and you need to get the highest score you can by avoiding damage and taking out enemies.  Get a high enough rating, and you can unlock the next mission.  There's 5 or 6 stages, and a Nightmare variation (more enemies, constant spawning instead of wave-based) for each.

Is it worth $15?  Yes, but it's not the best game out there.  My recommendation's to save up and buy the Alan Wake Franchise bundle, so you can get both titles.  If in doubt, wait for a Steam sale.

reviewText:
I actually liked this more than the regular campaign. This is kind of like a mix between the main campaign and a really basic open-world game.

It's a lot more open than the main campaign, but it's still rather linear, in that there is only ever one objective that can be done at a time, but you can roam around and explore. The areas aren't very big, and you can't freely travel between them, but this kind of gives me a taste of what the main campaign could have been like if it were designed as an open world game instead of being as utterly claustrophobic as it was.

This standalone DLC made quite a few changes from the original game, but not all of them were good. In the original Alan Wake, there were 4 weapons. In this one, there are 2 pistols, 2 rifles, 3 shotguns, 2 automatic weapons, a flaregun, and a nailgun. While choice is always good, some of the weapons are insanely overpowered, and some are just pointless. It seems like the developers took people's complaints about the main game's combat system to mean that combat was too difficult (it wasn't), and made it easier. Unfortunately, that means combat is now a cakewalk. Ammo is RIDICULOUSLY plentiful, weapons are insanely powerful, and enemies will barely ever even get close enough to hit you. Throughout the whole game, I got hit maybe 4 times, used 1 handheld flare, never fired the flaregun, and totally forgot I even HAD flashbangs.

They beefed up the flashlight as well. The enemies seem like they take less light to burn away the darkness, and the flashlight recharges CRAZY fast. From completely empty, it will charge to full in about 3 seconds, including the 1-2 second delay before it even starts charging. I was playing on Normal (there's only normal and nightmare), too, but maybe in this game that's the equivalent of easy.

The story is still rather interesting in this expansion, but the writing and voice acting are HORRIBLE. I mean absurdly stupid at times. I'm all for campy fun, but sometimes it gets so ridiculous that it really pulls you out of the experience. Speaking of acting, the little TV" segments where your dark self talks to you go on WAY too long sometimes
date: and don't really play any importance in how the game unfolds (and you don't get any achievements for them or anything).\n\nOverall I liked this. The story and acting took a step backwards from the main game
recommended: but you're not confined to the stupid outdoor tunnel sections (running through the woods)
hoursPlayed: and combat doesn't get in your way as horrifically as it did in the main game either.\n\nIt's rather short
voteText: so don't pay $20 for it or anything
helpfulPercent: but I enjoyed it. Your results may vary

reviewText:
Improves a bit on Alan Wake. Gameplay is a bit smoother and a bit more fun now, and areas are a lot less lineair which benefits the gameplay. Yet the core remains the same: aim your flashlight at an enemy for a few seconds and then shoot him until he drops.
The game is graphically stunning though and has high production values: it contains licensed music and even live action sequences.

I wasn't able to finish the game due to boredom, the improvement in gameplay just isn't enough. It's enjoyable to wander about in the game for fifteen minutes or so though, before shutting it down again.

6,5/10

reviewText:
I only understood the real meaning of Alan Wake`s American Nightmare when I was about an hour in the story. This must be a parody of Alan Wake. There cant be any other conclusion than this easy one. I mean everything, really everything what made Alan Wake a frightening and exciting experience was canceled in this game and replaced by an action based horror" shooter. I mean Alan with a M16 Fire Rifle? Really?? Dont get me wrong. You will get fun for a few hours. But is this worth the money? That is a question only you can answer to yourself. For me it was since I got this in a damn cheap Alan Wake bundle.

-Funny Shooting
-The evil Alan Wake in his Lifeaction videos was cool.
Cons:

-Story mode is about 2 hours long

-Extremly terrible dialogs. The narrator tries so hard to be all that dark and have a meaning full text but a powerful text does not always start with just a noun - a pause - and subsequent ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t text. "The observatory." "The village"
date: "A Man and a Woman-" herp derp\n\nI think this game would be much better if they did not try to give it a horror shooter ala Alan Wake atmospheric style. not even for 4.50€ with 50% off.

I hope you liked this review and you are a little bit clearer about this game.

reviewText:
They took one of the best things about the first game, the combat, and jacked it up big time and made it the main focus of this game. The first game you mainly did combat with lighter weapons like a pistol, pump shotgun, single shot hunting rifle, and flare gun. You also did a lot more walking around. Here, it's less walking around and almost purely combat. You get more enemies poured on you and you get a arsenal of guns right out of a action game, like assault rifles, nail gun, uzi, and whatever else. PC Gamer says it's not as good as the first game. PC Gamer also gave Duke Nukem Forever a score of 80/100 when everyone knows it should've been 80/1000 lol.
It's a really fun game with a great unique combat system. Where the first game was heavy on story, this just gets to what made that game so great and expands on it big time: the combat. And the story is cool too. Not as good as the story from the first game but still good. Game is a blast, 7.5/10.

reviewText: like the first one, reminds me of silent hill

If the first game's story was silent hill oriented, this DLC is Siren oriented. Can't say I enjoyed this one as much as the original game. The game felt more action based rather than Survival Horror. You'll find full ammo restock in certain places so there's no fear running out of ammo, which is bad as a surv. horror genre.\n\nThe original was a psychological horror this one felt more psycho thriller. This DLC was a good way to close the original game though.

American Nightmare drops the repetition from its predecessor by adding new weapons and types of enemies to mix things up with, and its plot makes clever use of the same three locations in a number of ways. The actual gameplay is as solid as ever, and the storyline, though shorter, is just as well-written, with a more personable foe in the form of Alan's nemesis, Mr. Scratch. However, it may be an issue to you that this one is nowhere near as scary as the original Alan Wake, and feels more like an action game.

Overall Score: 7/10
My advice: Wait 'til it drops under $7.50, only if you've played the first one.
Genre: Action/Survival Horror

As a small, semi-sequel to the original Alan Wake, AW:AN doesn't disappoint... much. For the $10 price tag, it's got enough content to keep you for a while. It's only about 6 hours long if you stop and get all the collectables, and Nightmare mode is difficult enough that I wasn't just breezing through every map. The arcade mode is also quite entertaining, but the enjoyment doesn't last. Story was the real reason the first game did well, and without it, the game's a little stale.

There's a somewhat interesting plot to story mode, which kept me mostly intrigued, and the familiar Alan Wake combat system is back, with only a few new enemies and guns. That's part of the reason I'm hesitant to call this a sequel... It's really just a new, small chapter of Alan Wake to tide the audience over for the next game, if there is one.

If the game drops below $7.50, I'd snag it. Was worth the time and effort. Be warned though, some of those achievements are a ♥♥♥♥♥ to get.
Wasn't quite immersive as the first game and I felt as though I never would run out of ammo.\nIf anything, I'd wait for it to go on sale.

What can I say about this game? It is one of the only games I have ever played, besides the first Alan Wake, that puts me on the edge of my seat and makes me feel like im in the game. This game has the perfect balance between story and action. I can honestly say that i would buy this game again if I could. It is that good.
